name: Device Identification And Authentication
description: The information system identifies and authenticates specific devices before establishing a connection.
supplemental_guidance: The information system typically uses either shared known information (e.g., Media Access Control (MAC) or Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) addresses) or an organizational authentication solution (e.g., IEEE 802.1x and Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) or a Radius server with EAP-Transport Layer Security (TLS) authentication) to identify and authenticate devices on local and/or wide area networks. The required strength of the device authentication mechanism is determined by the FIPS 199 security categorization of the information system with higher impact levels requiring stronger authentication.

attack_techniques.name: Data from Cloud Storage
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Device identification and authentication ensures that only authorised and verified devices can access cloud storage resources, preventing adversaries using unregistered or rogue devices from retrieving sensitive data stored in cloud environments.

attack_techniques.name: Transfer Data to Cloud Account
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Requiring device authentication before granting cloud connectivity prevents adversaries from transferring data to external cloud accounts from unidentified devices, as only organisationally registered endpoints can establish the necessary sessions.

attack_techniques.name: Unsecured Credentials
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Device-level authentication prevents unregistered systems from accessing credential stores and configuration repositories, limiting adversary ability to harvest unsecured credentials from devices that have not been authenticated to the network.

attack_techniques.name: Data from Configuration Repository
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Authenticating devices before allowing network access ensures that only verified infrastructure components can query configuration repositories, preventing adversaries on rogue devices from dumping network device configurations via management protocols.

attack_techniques.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Request Generation
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Device identification and authentication provides an additional verification layer that complements MFA, making it harder for adversaries to generate fraudulent MFA push notifications from unrecognised devices even if they possess valid user credentials.

attack_techniques.name: Cloud Instance Metadata API
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Device authentication controls restrict access to cloud instance metadata APIs to authenticated and authorised compute instances, preventing adversaries on rogue or compromised external devices from querying metadata endpoints for temporary credentials.

attack_techniques.name: SNMP (MIB Dump)
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Device identification requirements ensure that only authenticated network management stations can issue SNMP queries, preventing adversaries on unregistered devices from performing MIB dumps to collect sensitive configuration data.

attack_techniques.name: Network Device Configuration Dump
attack_techniques.mapping_rationale: Requiring device authentication before granting management plane access prevents unidentified systems from executing configuration dumps on network devices, blocking adversary collection of routing tables, ACLs, and credential material.
